title-group.article-title: Reliability of the Baltimore Activity Scale Questionnaire for Intermittent Claudication

article-meta.aff: 1School of Physical Education, University of Pernambuco, Pernambuco, Recife, PE, Brazil
2General Clinical Research Center, Oklahoma University Health Sciences Center (OUHSC), Oklahoma, OK, USA
3Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein, São Paulo, Brazil

author-notes.corresp: Raphael Mendes Ritti Dias, School of Physical Education, University of Pernambuco, Rua Arnóbio Marques, 310, Recife, PE 52050, Brazil Email: raphaelritti@gmail.com

abstract.p: We assessed the reliability of the Baltimore Activity Scale for Intermittent Claudication (BASIC) for the evaluation of physical activity levels in individuals with intermittent claudication. We also identify the characteristics of the patients that influence the reliability of this questionnaire. A total of 38 men and women with peripheral artery disease and symptoms of intermittent claudication participated in the study. BASIC was administered to patients by the same evaluator at 2 different visits, separated by 7 days. The concordance coefficient ranged from .43 (How often do you walk at a fast pace?) to .85 (What happens when you feel pain while you walk?). The concordance coefficient of BASIC total score was .60. Higher concordance coefficients were observed in women (.66 vs .55), in younger patients (.63 vs .56), and in patients with lower ankle–brachial index (.64 vs .55). The reliability of BASIC questionnaire ranged from moderate to good in patients with claudication.

kwd-group.kwd: Baltimore Activity Scale for Intermittent Claudication

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Intermittent claudication (IC) is a common symptom of peripheral artery disease (PAD). IC is caused by a reduction in arterial oxygen delivery to the leg during exercise 1 due to arterial obstruction 2–4 and is associated with reduced quality of life. 5

Patients with IC have lower physical activity levels than controls during low-, medium-, and high-intensity physical activities. 6 Moreover, among patients with PAD, those who were more physically inactive had lower functional capacity and higher cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. 7,8 Thus, the measurement of physical activity levels in these patients could help to identify those who are at higher risk.

Physical activity in patients with PAD can be accurately and reliably assessed using movement sensors. 9,10 However, this costly and time-consuming process limits its routine use. An alternative method for the assessment of physical activity is the Baltimore Activity Scale for Intermittent Claudication (BASIC) questionnaire developed exclusively for patients with PAD. This questionnaire has 5 questions regarding the functional limitations of individuals with IC and was validated against the accelerometer. 11 Although the validity of BASIC has been reported, its reliability has not been established.
The aim of this study was to verify the reliability of BASIC in individuals with IC and to identify the characteristics that may influence its reliability.

sec.title: Patient Recruitment and Screening
sec.p: A total of 38 patients enrolled in a tertiary center specialized in vascular disease were recruited for the study. Patients were included in the study if they met the following criteria: Fontaine stage II PAD, 12 symptoms of IC for at least 6 months, ankle–brachial index (ABI) at rest ≤0.90 in 1 or 2 legs, and exercise tolerance limited by IC. Patients were excluded under the following conditions: the presence of chronic lung disease, inability to obtain ABI measurement due to noncompressible vessels, exercise tolerance limited by factors other than claudication (eg, dyspnea or orthopedic problems), and history of revascularization in the previous year.

This study was approved by the Joint Committee on Ethics of Human Research of the University of Pernambuco. Each patient was informed about the procedures of the study and signed a written informed consent before participation.

sec.title: Clinical Characteristics
sec.p: Demographic information, cardiovascular risk factors, comorbid conditions, and ABI 13 were obtained during a medical history interview before evaluation.

sec.title: BASIC Questionnaire
sec.p: Physical activity level was assessed using the BASIC questionnaire, which is composed of 5 questions (Appendix A). The questions address items regarding the development of IC as well as the capacity to walk before feeling pain, attitude taken at the onset of the pain, walking speed, walking up and down slopes and stairs. Patients chose the answer that best described their symptoms and physical activity levels. The scores ranged between 0 and 2 points and the total score was the sum of points from the 5 questions.
Based on the total BASIC score, daily physical activity was predicted by the following regression equation:
Daily Physical Activity (kcal/d) = 102.2 + (49.6 × BASIC score);
Based on the validation study, 11 this equation had R = .76, R 2 = .58, standard error of estimate = 52.0 kcal/d, P < .0001.

sec.title: Reliability of BASIC
sec.p: To assess reliability, BASIC was applied at 2 distinct visits with an interval of 7 days between them. Both interviews were performed in a quiet room by the same evaluator. During the study period, patients were instructed not to change their physical activity patterns.

To identify the characteristics of the patients that might influence the reliability of BASIC questionnaire, patients were stratified according to gender, ABI (≤0.60 and >0.60), and age (≤65 years or >66 years), and the reliability was established for each category.

sec.title: Statistical Analyses
sec.p: Data are presented in median and interquartile range. Wilcoxon test was used to analyze the differences between the 2 visits for each question in the BASIC questionnaire. The weighted Kappa index was used for concordance analysis. Intraclass correlation coefficient was employed to analyze the reliability of energy expenditure estimated by the BASIC. The Analysis of Bland-Altman was performed for concordance analysis between the estimate of energy expenditure provided by the questionnaire in both visits. Statistical significance was P < .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The patients' clinical characteristics are summarized in Table 1 and the scores and the concordance coefficients in each question are presented in Table 2 . The scores obtained were similar between visits, except for question 4 (P < .05). The concordance coefficients of the questions ranged from 0.43 (question 3) to 0.85 (question 2). The concordance coefficient of the total score was 0.60.

tr.td: ABI in the most affected leg

fn.p: a Values are mean (standard deviation) or percentage of patients.

caption.p: Scores Provided in Each Question in Each Occasion and Kappa Correlation Coefficienta

tr.td: 1. How many blocks can you walk before you feel pain in your leg?
2. What happens when you feel the pain while you walk?
3. How often do you walk at a fast pace?
4. How often do you walk up- and downstairs?
5. How often do you walk up and down hills?

fn.p: a Values for visits 1 and 2 are median (interquartile range).

sec.p: The estimated energy expenditure provided by the questionnaire was similar between the 2 visits (P > .05). The analysis of the agreement of the estimated energy expenditure according to Bland-Altman plot is presented in Figure 1. The bias between the estimated values obtained in the 2 visits was −16 kcal and the limits of agreement ranged from −117 to +250 kcal. Almost all patients were inside the limits of agreement. The reliability coefficient of the energy expenditure estimate was 0.87 (CI 95%: 0.74-0.93).

caption.p: Bland-Altman plot of energy expenditure estimation in the 2 visits.

sec.p: Analyses of concordance coefficients of total score according to clinical characteristics are summarized in Table 3 . Higher concordance coefficients between visits were observed in women, in younger patients, and in patients with lower ABI.

caption.p: Total Score in Each Visit and Kappa Concordance Coefficient According to Clinical Characteristics

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The main findings of this study were as follows: (i) the reliability coefficient of the BASIC questionnaire ranged from moderate to high; (ii) the estimated energy expenditure using the BASIC questionnaire presented good reliability; (iii) the reliability of BASIC questionnaire is higher in women, in younger patients, and in patients with lower ABI.

The reliability coefficients observed in this study ranged from moderate to high. Although these values are lower than the previously reported values in patients with PAD using movement sensors, 9,10 the reliability coefficients observed using BASIC were similar to the ones previously reported in elderly patients and is within the range of the questionnaires that assess physical activity. 14–16 In the present study, we observed that questions 1 (How many blocks can you walk before you feel pain in your leg?) and 2 (What happens when you feel the pain while you walk?) presented the highest concordance coefficients. Interestingly, Gardner and Montgomery 11 reported that these questions are the main predictors of energy expenditure in patients with claudication, indicating that the questions most related to energy expenditure in patients with PAD are the most reliable.

In most of the questions, the average responses in visit 2 were not different from the responses in visit 1. These results support the use of BASIC questionnaire to analyze the changes in physical activity levels after interventions since the responses remain stable between the applications. In fact, a previous study observed that the BASIC questionnaire was sensitive to detect changes in physical activity levels after an exercise rehabilitation program. 11 On the other hand, in question 4 (How often do you walk up- and downstairs?) was different between the 2 visits. This result might be caused by the low frequency of high-intensity activities, 6 which raise doubts about which is the best answer among rarely/never or sometimes.

The estimated energy expenditure of patients with PAD is based on the total score of the BASIC questionnaire. In the regression model, the unstandardized regression coefficient indicates that each point corresponds to 49.6 kcal/d of physical activity. Interestingly, the reliability coefficient of the estimated energy expenditure by the BASIC questionnaire was .87, which was higher than the concordance coefficient of the total score that was .60. The differences between the reliability coefficients of energy expenditure and total score can be explained by the different statistical procedures employed due to different characteristics of variables (continuous vs discrete). According to the Bland-Altman plots, the mean difference in the estimated energy expenditure between visits was approximately −16 kcal. In addition, in most of the patients, the differences in the estimated energy expenditure between visits were lower than 100 kcal. Therefore, the estimation of energy expenditure based on the BASIC results seems to be consistent in these patients.

The reliability of the total score of BASIC questionnaire is influenced by gender, age, and the severity of PAD. Women and patients with lower ABI have higher reliability coefficients than men and patients with higher ABI, respectively. We have previously found that women with PAD are 18% less active than men, 17 whereas several studies have indicated that a lower ABI is related to lower physical activity levels in these patients. 7,18,19 Collectively, these results suggest that greater reliability coefficients of the BASIC questionnaire are obtained in patients who are less active. The greater reliability of BASIC questionnaire in younger patients might be attributed to a better cognitive function in these patients, 20 leading to a more accurate description of the physical activity levels.

The results of this study support the use of the BASIC questionnaire in clinical practice. Although the movement sensors are accurate, their use is limited due to high cost and long time for data analysis. Considering our results, the BASIC questionnaire is a reliable instrument to assess physical activity in patients with PAD. Therefore, it is possible to identify patients who may be at higher risk of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality due to inadequate physical activity levels and to assess changes in physical activity levels after interventions.

This study has limitations. The sample was composed of patients with PAD and symptoms of IC and the results should be applied to a group of patients who have similar characteristics to that of the present study. The visits were performed with a 7-day difference between them. Although this procedure has been widely used to analyze reliability, few differences in patients' physical activity levels might have occurred between visits.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The BASIC questionnaire presents moderate-to-high-reliability coefficients to assess physical activity levels in patients with PAD limited by IC. The reliability of the questionnaire is higher in women, in patients with lower ABI and younger age.

fn.p: The scoring for each question is as follows: a = 0 points, b = 1 point, c = 2 points. The BASIC total score is the sum of points from the 5 questions.
The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

The authors disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: the Programa de Apoio de Fortalecimento Acadêmico da Universidade de Pernambuco.

sec.title: Baltimore Activity Scale for Intermittent Claudication (BASIC)

list-item.p:
Please circle the appropriate number (a, b, or c) that best describes your answer to each question.
How many blocks can you walk before you feel pain in your leg?
Less than 1 block.
Between 1 and 2 blocks.
More than 2 blocks.
What happens when you feel the pain while you walk?
Stop walking.
Slow down.
Continue walking at the same pace.
How often do you walk at a fast pace?
Rarely/never.
Sometimes.
Frequently.
How often do you walk up- and downstairs?
Rarely/never.
Sometimes.
Frequently.
How often do you walk up and down hills?
Rarely/never.
Sometimes.
Frequently.
